Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: A I04iend sends a text message complaining about having a long, boring day.
Expectation2: Secure packages and confirm successful delivery
Situation2: Leaving a package safely at the doorstep when no one is home
Story: My phone buzzed just as I pulled up to the next house on my delivery route. It was Mia, my best friend, texting, “Ugh, today’s been endless. Can you talk?” I knew she needed me to listen, to be there for her like always. But as I read her message, I glanced at the package in my passenger seat, double-checking the address. The instructions were clear: leave it at the doorstep, take a photo, and make sure it’s safe. The neighborhood wasn’t the best, and I’d been warned about porch pirates. I felt the pressure mounting—Mia expected me to reply right away, to give her my full attention, but my job demanded I focus on the delivery, secure the package, and move on quickly. My thumb hovered over my phone, torn between sending a comforting reply and doing my job by the book. I could almost hear Mia’s voice in my head, needing me, while my supervisor’s reminders echoed just as loudly. My heart pounded as I stood at the curb, wrestling with what to do next.
